column4: Hello, I'm having trouble with what windows terms "Internet Connection Sharing", in that my ubuntu laptop is connected via an ethernet cable to my WinXP tower, which is in tern connected via modem to the internet. It worked for about five hours, but has suddenly ceased functioning and I cannot think of anything having been done which could have caused a problem.
Are you talking about some type of file server? Take a look at samba or nfs (both have great tutorials online)
If you right click on a directory while in the gnome desktop environment, you should be able to select 'share this file' or some such.
No, that's not really what I'm on about.
Oh, you want your windows box to act as a router
Sorry*, Rummage: You want your windows machine to act as a routeR?
Windows has this feature called Internet Connection sharing, where Computer B on a network, say LAN, can use computer A's internet connection.
I wouldn't trust windows for anything. Especially networking. I suggest asking the windows folks.
I'm betting windows is at fault, but I still can't figure out why it would quit suddenly with no changes.
I mean, I actually managed to use it to update Synaptic and install VLC :\
I don't know why you're asking a car mechanic to fix your broken television set.
Because there are car mechanics around, and the TV repairman show's up days late and with terrible advice.
Fine, fair enough. My suggestion is to format that windows machine and but some flavor of GNU Linux on it.
It looks like that's my only recourse.
You haven't tried restarting the machine?...
mek: It's a thing of last resort, as you may be familiar, windows machines are terribly ornery when it comes to rebooting.
I think that's the first thing I'd retry.
Well, see, it takes longer to reboot than it has taken to ascertain that's the only idea we've got here.
Either that or ipconfig /release all and then try to renew your network information
